J	Lee, CMC; So, EC; Wang, CCY				Lee, Charles M. C.; So, Eric C.; Wang, Charles C. Y.			Evaluating Firm-Level Expected-Return Proxies: Implications for Estimating Treatment Effects	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							CROSS-SECTION; IMPLIED COST; MARKET EQUILIBRIUM; EQUITY; EXPECTATIONS; RISK; DISCLOSURE; INFORMATION; INVESTMENT; VOLATILITY	We introduce a parsimonious framework for choosing among alternative expected-return proxies (ERPs) when estimating treatment effects. By comparing ERPs' measurement error variances in the cross-section and in the time series, we provide new evidence on the relative performance of firm-level ERPs nominated by recent studies. Generally, "implied-costs-of-capital" metrics perform best in the time series, whereas "characteristic-based" proxies perform best in the cross-section. Factor-based ERPs, even the latest renditions, perform poorly. We revisit four prior studies that use ex ante ERPs and illustrate how this framework can potentially alter either the sign or the magnitude of prior inferences.	[Lee, Charles M. C.] Stanford Univ, Grad Sch Business, Stanford, CA 94305 USA; [So, Eric C.] MIT, Sloan Sch Management, 77 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA; [Wang, Charles C. J	Heath, D; Macciocchi, D; Michaely, R; Ringgenberg, MC				Heath, Davidson; Macciocchi, Daniele; Michaely, Roni; Ringgenberg, Matthew C.			Do Index Funds Monitor?	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							CORPORATE GOVERNANCE; REGRESSION-DISCONTINUITY; SHAREHOLDER ACTIVISM; INSTITUTIONAL OWNERSHIP; FIRM; COSTS; TIES; PAY	Passively managed index funds now hold over 30 of U.S. equity fund assets; this shift raises fundamental questions about monitoring and governance. We show that, relative to active funds, index funds are less effective monitors: (a) they are less likely to vote against firm management on contentious governance issues; (b) there is no evidence they engage effectively publicly or privately; and (c) they promote less board independence and worse pay-performance sensitivity at their portfolio companies. Overall, the rise of index funds decreases the alignment of incentives between beneficial owners and firm management and shifts control from investors to managers.	[Heath, Davidson; Ringgenberg, Matthew C.] Univ Utah, David Eccles Sch Business, Salt Lake City, UT 84112 USA; [Macciocchi, Daniele] Univ Miami, Miami Herbert Business Sch, Coral Gables, FL 33124 USA; [Michaely, Roni] Univ Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Peoples R China; [Michaely, Roni] ECGI, Brussels, Belgium	Utah System of Higher Education; University of Utah; University of Miami; University of Hong Kong; European Corporate Governance Institute	Ringgenberg, MC (corresponding author), Univ Utah, David Eccles Sch Business, Salt Lake City, UT 84112 USA.	matthew.ringgenberg@eccles.utah.edu	Ringgenberg, Matthew/GNH-6415-2022					ADMATI AR, 1994, J POLIT ECON, V102, P1097, DOI 10.1086/261965; Aghion P, 2013, AM ECON REV, V103, P277, DOI 10.1257/aer.103.1.277; Appel I., 2019, IDENTIFICATION USING; Appel IR, 2019, REV FINANC STUD, V32, P2720, DOI 10.1093/rfs/hhy106; Appel IR, 2016, J FINANC ECON, V121, P111, DOI 10.1016/j.jfineco.2016.03.003; Azar J, 2018, J FINANC, V73, P1513, DOI 10.1111/jofi.12698; Back K, 2018, ECONOMETRICA, V86, P1431, DOI 10.3982/ECTA14917; Bebchuk L.A., 2019, B U L REV, V99, P721; Bebchuk L, 2019, COLUMBIA LAW REV, V119, P2029; Bebchuk L, 2009, REV FINANC STUD, V22, P783, DOI 10.1093/rfs/hhn099; Bebchuk LA, 2017, J ECON PERSPECT, V31, P89, DOI 10.1257/jep.31.3.89; Ben-David, MANAGE SCI; Berle A., 1932, MODERN CORPORATE PRI; BHIDE A, 1993, J FINANC ECON, V34, P31, DOI 10.1016/0304-405X(93)90039-E; BLOOM HS, 1995, EVALUATION REV, V19, P547, DOI 10.1177/0193841X9501900504; Bolton P, 2020, J FINANC ECON, V137, P320, DOI 10.1016/j.jfineco.2020.03.004; Boone AL, 2015, J FINANC ECON, V117, P508, DOI 10.1016/j.jfineco.2015.05.008; Brav A., 2019, PICKING FRIENDS PICK; Brav A, 2008, J FINANC, V63, P1729, DOI 10.1111/j.1540-6261.2008.01373.x; Bubb R., 2018, PARTY STRUCTURE MUTU; Burkart M, 1997, Q J ECON, V112, P693, DOI 10.1162/003355397555325; Chang YC, 2015, REV FINANC STUD, V28, P212, DOI 10.1093/rfs/hhu041; Coles J. J	Acharya, VV; Borchert, L; Jager, M; Steffen, S				Acharya, Viral V.; Borchert, Lea; Jager, Maximilian; Steffen, Sascha			Kicking the Can Down the Road: Government Interventions in the European Banking Sector	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							MORAL HAZARD; BAILOUTS; FAILURES; CREDIT; RISK; TARP; TIME; TOO; PERFORMANCE; INCENTIVES	We analyze government interventions in the eurozone banking sector during the 2008-2009 financial crisis. Using a novel data set, we document that fiscally constrained governments "kicked the can down the road" by providing banks with guarantees instead of fully-fledged recapitalizations. We econometrically address the endogeneity associated with bailout decisions in identifying their consequences. We find that forbearance prompted undercapitalized banks to shift their assets from loans to risky sovereign debt and engage in zombie lending, resulting in weaker credit supply, elevated risk in the banking sector, and, eventually, a greater reliance on liquidity support from the European Central Bank. J	Babina, T; Jotikasthira, C; Lundblad, C; Ramadorai, T				Babina, Tania; Jotikasthira, Chotibhak; Lundblad, Christian; Ramadorai, Tarun			Heterogeneous Taxes and Limited Risk Sharing: Evidence from Municipal Bonds	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							CORPORATE YIELD SPREADS; MARKET-SEGMENTATION; PORTFOLIO CHOICE; ASSET PRICES; GOVERNMENT POLICY; SIMPLE-MODEL; DEBT; EQUILIBRIUM; LIQUIDITY; DEMAND	We evaluate the impacts of tax policy on asset returns using the U.S. municipal bond market. In theory, tax-induced ownership segmentation limits risk sharing, creating downward-sloping regions of the aggregate demand curve for the asset. In the data, cross-state variation in tax privilege policies predicts differences in in-state ownership of local municipal bonds; the policies create incentives for concentrated local ownership. High tax privilege states have muni bond yields that are more sensitive to variations in supply and local idiosyncratic risk. The effects are stronger when local investors face correlated background risk and/or diminishing marginal nonpecuniary benefits from holding local assets. J	Fleckenstein, M; Longstaff, FA				Fleckenstein, Matthias; Longstaff, Francis A.			Renting Balance Sheet Space: Intermediary Balance Sheet Rental Costs and the Valuation of Derivatives	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							EMPIRICAL-ANALYSIS; MARKET LIQUIDITY; YIELD SPREADS; RISK PREMIA; ARBITRAGE; DEFAULT; PRICE; DEBT; CONSTRAINTS; SECURITIES	A long-standing asset pricing puzzle is that the funding rates in derivatives contracts often differ from those in cash markets. We propose that the cost of renting intermediary balance sheet space may help resolve this puzzle. We study a persistent basis in what is arguably the largest derivatives market, namely, the interest rate futures market. This basis is strongly related to exogenous measures of intermediary balance sheet usage and proxies for the balance sheet costs imposed by debt overhang problems and capital regulation. These results extend to the cash derivatives bases documented in many of the other largest financial markets. J	Donaldson, JR; Malenko, N; Piacentino, G				Donaldson, Jason Roderick; Malenko, Nadya; Piacentino, Giorgia			Deadlock on the Board	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							STAGGERED BOARDS; CEO; DIVERSITY; DIRECTORS; INDEPENDENCE; ENTRENCHMENT; SHAREHOLDERS; MARKET	We develop a dynamic model of board decision-making akin to dynamic voting models in the political economy literature. We show a board could retain a policy all directors agree is worse than an available alternative. Thus, directors may retain a CEO they agree is bad-deadlocked boards lead to entrenched CEOs. We explore how to compose boards and appoint directors to mitigate deadlock. We find board diversity and long director tenure can exacerbate deadlock. We rationalize why CEOs and incumbent directors have power to appoint new directors: to avoid deadlock. Our model speaks to short-termism, staggered boards, and proxy access. J	Chava, S; Hsu, A				Chava, Sudheer; Hsu, Alex			Financial Constraints, Monetary Policy Shocks, and the Cross-Section of Equity Returns	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							INTEREST-RATES; STOCK; CREDIT; TRANSMISSION; PRICES	We analyze the impact of unanticipated monetary policy changes on the cross-section of U.S. equity returns. Financially constrained firms earn a significantly lower (higher) return following surprise interest rate increases (decreases) as compared to unconstrained firms. This differential return response between constrained and unconstrained firms appears after a delay of 3 to 4 days. Further, unanticipated Federal funds rate increases are associated with a larger decrease in expected cash flow news, but not discount rate news, for constrained firms relative to unconstrained firms. J	Li, QY; Lin, C; Xu, L				Li, Qingyuan; Lin, Chen; Xu, Li			Political Investment Cycles of State-Owned Enterprises	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							OPERATING PERFORMANCE; GOVERNMENT OWNERSHIP; PRIVATIZED FIRMS; PANEL-DATA; UNCERTAINTY; FINANCE; MARKET; BANKS; TESTS; LAW	Using a large panel of more than 140,000 state-owned enterprises (SOEs), this study examines SOEs' investment behavior surrounding 82 national elections in 25 European countries between 2001 and 2015. We find that SOEs increase their corporate investment by about 29% of the sample average during national election years. This effect is more pronounced in fixed timing and closely contested elections. The effect is also stronger in countries with low institutional quality, more centralized political systems, and state-controlled banking systems. In contrast, we find the matched non-SOEs significantly decrease their corporate investment during national election years.	[Li, Qingyuan] Wuhan Univ, Econ & Management Sch, Wuhan, Hubei, Peoples R China; [Lin, Chen] Univ Hong Kong, Fac Business & Econ, Hong Kong, Peoples R China; [Xu, Li] Washington State Univ, Pullman, WA 99164 USA	Wuhan University; University of Hong Kong; Washington State University	Lin, C (corresponding author), Univ Hong Kong, Fac Business & Econ, Hong Kong, Peoples R China.	chenlin1@hku.hk		Xu, Li/0000-0002-8043-2481	Natural Science Foundation of China [71672129]; National Social Science Fund of China [18ZDA113]; National Natural Science Foundation of China [71790601]; University of Hong Kong; College of Business at Washington State University	Natural Science Foundation of China(National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC)); National Social Science Fund of China; National Natural Science Foundation of China(National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC)); University of Hong Kong(University of Hong Kong); College of Business at Washington State University	We thank the editor (Andrew Karolyi) and the anonymous reviewer for very constructive and helpful comments. J	Gallagher, EA; Schmidt, LDW; Timmermann, A; Wermers, R				Gallagher, Emily A.; Schmidt, Lawrence D. W.; Timmermann, Allan; Wermers, Russ			Investor Information Acquisition and Money Market Fund Risk Rebalancing during the 2011-2012 Eurozone Crisis	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							CREDIT RISK; LIQUIDITY; SAFE; SECURITIES; ATTENTION; RUNS	We study investor redemptions and portfolio rebalancing decisions of prime money market mutual funds (MMFs) during the Eurozone crisis. We find that sophisticated investors selectively acquire information about MMFs' risk exposures to Europe, which leads managers to withdraw funding from information-sensitive European issuers. That is, MMF managers, particularly those serving the most sophisticated investors, selectively adjust their portfolio risk exposures to avoid information-sensitive European risks, while maintaining or increasing risk exposures to other regions. This mechanism helps to explain the occurrence of selective "dry-ups" in debt markets where delegation is common and returns to information production are usually low. J	Jermann, UJ				Jermann, Urban J.			Negative Swap Spreads and Limited Arbitrage	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							PORTFOLIO; DEFAULT; COSTS; RISK	Since October 2008, fixed rates for interest rate swaps with a 30-year maturity have been mostly below Treasury rates with the same maturity. Under standard assumptions, this implies the existence of arbitrage opportunities. This paper presents a model for pricing interest rate swaps, where frictions for holding bonds limit arbitrage. I analytically show that negative swap spreads should not be surprising. In the calibrated model, swap spreads can reasonably match empirical counterparts without the need for large demand imbalances in the swap market. Empirical evidence is consistent with the relation between term spreads and swap spreads in the model.	[Jermann, Urban J.] Univ Penn, Wharton Sch, 3620 Locust Walk, Philadelphia, PA 19104 USA; [Jermann, Urban J.] NBER, Cambridge, MA 02138 USA	University of Pennsylvania; National Bureau of Economic Research	Jermann, UJ (corresponding author), Univ Penn, Wharton Sch, 3620 Locust Walk, Philadelphia, PA 19104 USA.	jermann@wharton.upenn.edu						Andersen L, 2019, J FINANC, V74, P145, DOI 10.1111/jofi.12739; Bowman L., 2016, EUROMONEY; Collin-Dufresne P, 2001, J FINANC, V56, P1095, DOI 10.1111/0022-1082.00357; DOW J, 1994, J FINANC, V49, P819, DOI 10.2307/2329208; Duffie D, 2018, MANAGE SCI, V64, P4835, DOI 10.1287/mnsc.2017.2768; Eom Y., 2002, J FIXED INCOME, V12, P6; Faulkender M, 2005, J FINANC, V60, P931, DOI 10.1111/j.1540-6261.2005.00751.x; Feldhutter P, 2008, J FINANC ECON, V88, P375, DOI 10.1016/j.jfineco.2007.07.004; Garleanu N, 2009, REV FINANC STUD, V22, P4259, DOI 10.1093/rfs/hhp005; Gospodinov N, 2014, J APPL ECONOMET, V29, P843, DOI 10.1002/jae.2354; Greenwood Robin, 2017, BROOKINGS PAPERS EC; Gromb D, 2010, ANNU REV FINANC ECON, V2, P251, DOI 10.1146/annurev-financial-073009-104107; Gupta A, 2000, J FINANC ECON, V55, P239, DOI 10.1016/S0304-405X(99)00051-3; Hanson SG, 2014, J FINANC ECON, V113, P270, DOI 10.1016/j.jfineco.2014.05.002; Jermann UJ, 2018, J ECON DYN CONTROL, V88, P104, DOI 10.1016/j.jedc.2018.01.022; Johannes M, 2007, J FINANC, V62, P383, DOI 10.1111/j.1540-6261.2007.01210.x; Judd K. J	Iyer, R; Laerkholm Jensen, T; Johannesen, N; Sheridan, A				Iyer, Rajkamal; Laerkholm Jensen, Thais; Johannesen, Niels; Sheridan, Adam			The Distortive Effects of Too Big To Fail: Evidence from the Danish Market for Retail Deposits	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							INSURANCE; RISK	We study the impact of too-big-to-fail (TBTF) guarantees on the market for retail deposits. Exploiting information about all personal deposit accounts in Denmark and salient changes to the deposit insurance limit, we provide evidence that systemically important banks successfully retain and attract uninsured deposits in a crisis at the expense of other banks even as they differentially lower their interest rates. The funding shock suffered by nonsystemic banks causes a decrease in their lending. The results point to the distortive effects of TBTF guarantees in the market for retail deposits.	[Iyer, Rajkamal] Imperial Coll London, London, England; [Laerkholm Jensen, Thais; Johannesen, Niels; Sheridan, Adam] Univ Copenhagen, Copenhagen, Denmark; [Laerkholm Jensen, Thais] Danmarks Nationalbank, Copenhagen, Denmark; [Johannesen, Niels; Sheridan, Adam] CEBI, Oster Farimagsgade 5, DK-1353 Copenhagen, Denmark	Imperial College London; University of Copenhagen	Johannesen, N (corresponding author), CEBI, Oster Farimagsgade 5, DK-1353 Copenhagen, Denmark.; Johannesen, N (corresponding author), Univ Copenhagen, Dept Econ, Oster Farimagsgade 5, DK-1353 Copenhagen, Denmark.	niels.johannesen@econ.ku.dk		Iyer, Rajkamal/0000-0002-3193-0441; Sheridan, Adam/0000-0002-4570-9481; johannesen, niels/0000-0002-7850-2794	Danish National Research Foundation	Danish National Research Foundation(Danmarks Grundforskningsfond)	We thank Puriya Abbassi, Nittai Bergman, Doug Diamond, Antoinette Schoar, Andrei Shleifer, Jeremy Stein, Phil Strahan, and Haluk Unal and seminar participants at the University of Maryland, Wharton, HEC Paris, the University of Zurich, the University of Oxford, the University of St Andrews, NUS, Imperial College, UCLA, Federal Reserve Board, Danmarks Nationalbank, and FDIC for comments. J	Grieser, W; Liu, Z				Grieser, William; Liu, Zack			Corporate Investment and Innovation in the Presence of Competitor Constraints	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							FINANCIAL CONSTRAINTS; BANKRUPTCY; DEBT; CONTAGION; MATTER	We study the relation between investment behavior and competitor financial constraints. Using interfirm patent citations and text-based product market similarities to identify intransitive competitor networks, we find that firms increase investment spending, patenting activity, and opportunistic hiring when competitor constraints become more binding. In addition, firms shift their investment composition (product market and patent portfolios) to compete more aggressively with relatively constrained competitors. To mitigate endogeneity concerns, we exploit the 2004 AJCA tax holiday and the 1989 junk bond crisis as exogenous shocks to competitor constraints, and we find similar effects. J	Santos, JAC; Winton, A				Santos, Joao A. C.; Winton, Andrew			Bank Capital, Borrower Power, and Loan Rates	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							INFORMATION RENTS; RISK-MANAGEMENT	We examine how bank capital and borrower bargaining power affect loan spreads. Consistent with previous studies, higher bank capital has a negative impact on loan rates, but borrower cash flow has a significant effect on this impact: compared with high-capital banks, low-capital banks charge more for borrowers with low cash flow, but offer greater marginal discounts as these borrowers' cash flow rises. These effects are largely focused on more bank-dependent borrowers. We find some evidence that low-capital banks charge a higher premium for bank-dependent borrowers' systematic risk, but not for their total equity risk or default risk.	[Santos, Joao A. J	Belo, F; Lin, XJ; Yang, F				Belo, Frederico; Lin, Xiaoji; Yang, Fan			External Equity Financing Shocks, Financial Flows, and Asset Prices	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							ENDOGENOUS LIQUIDITY; CROSS-SECTION; AGENCY COSTS; NET WORTH; STOCK; INVESTMENT; RISK; ISSUES; FLUCTUATIONS; DECISIONS	We develop a dynamic model with time variation in external equity financing costs and show that variation in these costs is important for the model to quantitatively capture the joint dynamics of firms' asset prices, real quantities, and financial flows in the U.S. economy. Growth firms and high investment firms are less risky in equilibrium, because they can substitute more easily debt financing for equity financing when it becomes more costly to raise external equity, which are high marginal utility states. Using a model-implied proxy of aggregate equity issuance cost shocks, we provide empirical support for the model's economic mechanism. J	Lowry, M; Rossi, M; Zhu, ZY				Lowry, Michelle; Rossi, Marco; Zhu, Zhongyan			Informed Trading by Advisor Banks: Evidence from Options Holdings	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							INFORMATIONAL CONTENT; CORPORATE GOVERNANCE; PRICES; MARKET; VOLUME; ACQUISITION; INSIDERS; RETURNS; BOARDS; SIDE	Strong conflicts of interest exist within investment banks: the investment banking division possesses substantial private information, and the asset management division seeks such information. This raises the question of whether the asset management division benefits from an information advantage on client firms. While prior examinations of advisor bank trading in client firms have focused on stocks and found mixed results, we argue that the options market represents a more attractive venue for such trading. We find significant evidence of advisor banks trading in client firm options ahead of merger announcements, but no evidence of similar trading in client firm stock. J	Barardehi, YH; Bernhardt, D; Davies, RJ				Barardehi, Yashar H.; Bernhardt, Dan; Davies, Ryan J.			Trade-Time Measures of Liquidity	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							MARKET MICROSTRUCTURE; CROSS-SECTION; PRICES; ILLIQUIDITY; SIXTEENTHS; INFERENCE; RETURNS; MODEL; RISK	Dramatic microstructure changes in equity markets have made standard liquidity measures less accurate proxies for trading costs. We develop trade-time liquidity measures that reflect per-dollar price impacts of fixed-dollar volumes. Our measures better capture institutional trading costs and better explain the cross-section of returns than do standard measures, especially in recent years. Despite improvements in measures of market quality, expected trading costs have explanatory power for the cross-section of expected returns: we obtain monthly liquidity premium estimates of 5.3 bp for expected returns and 2.4 bp for risk-adjusted returns. Estimated premiums rise after the financial crisis and remain high thereafter. Received April 15, 2016; editorial decision December 24, 2017 by Editor Andrew Karolyi. J	Stanton, R; Walden, J; Wallace, N				Stanton, Richard; Walden, Johan; Wallace, Nancy			Mortgage Loan Flow Networks and Financial Norms	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							SOCIAL-STRUCTURE; SYSTEMIC RISK; CRISIS	We develop a theoretical model of a network of intermediaries whose optimal behavior is jointly determined, leading to heterogeneous financial norms and systemic vulnerabilities. We apply the model to the network of U.S. mortgage intermediaries from 2005 to 2007, using a data set containing all private-label, fixed-rate mortgages, with loan flows defining links. Default risk was closely related to network position, evolving predictably among linked nodes, and loan quality estimated from the model was related to independent quality measures, altogether pointing to the vital importance of network effects in this market. J	Monnet, C; Quintin, E				Monnet, Cyril; Quintin, Erwan			Rational Opacity	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							INFORMATION; INVESTMENT; PRIVATE; BANKS; TRANSPARENCY; TRADE; RISK	We present an environment in which long-term investors sometimes choose to restrict how much fundamental information they receive about the value of their investment to preserve its liquidity in secondary markets. When and only when there is a risk that secondary markets may be shallow, more information can reduce the expected payoff of agents who need to cash out early. Even given direct and costless control over information design, stakeholders choose to incentivize managers to withhold interim information. In such an environment, imposing transparency can lower investment and welfare. J	Demir, B; Michalski, TK; Ors, E				Demir, Banu; Michalski, Tomasz K.; Ors, Evren			Risk-Based Capital Requirements for Banks and International Trade	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							REGULATORY ARBITRAGE; CRISIS	We test the trade finance channel of exports by controlling for the bank credit channel. Using Turkey's July 2012 adoption of Basel II as a quasi-natural experiment, we examine whether shocks to trade financing costs affect exports. With data for 16,662 Turkish exporters shipping 2,888 different products to 158 countries, we find that the share of letters-of-credit-based exports decreases (increases) when the associated risk weights for counterparty exposure increase (decrease) after the adoption of Basel II. However, growth of firm-product-country-level exports remains unaffected. Trade financing might have a lesser role in exports than previously suggested by the previous literature.	[Demir, Banu] Bilkent Univ, Ankara, Turkey; [Michalski, Tomasz K.; Ors, Evren] HEC Paris, Jouy En Josas, France	Ihsan Dogramaci Bilkent University; Hautes Etudes Commerciales (HEC) Paris	Ors, E (corresponding author), HEC Paris, Dept Finance, F-78351 Jouy En Josas, France.	ors@hec.fr		Ors, Evren/0000-0003-3184-3329; Demir, Banu/0000-0003-0183-6099; Michalski, Tomasz/0000-0002-5021-6809	French National Research Agency (ANR) [ANR-11-IDEX-0003/Labex Ecodec/ANR-11-LABX-0047]	French National Research Agency (ANR)(French National Research Agency (ANR))	We thank Philip Strahan (the editor) and two anonymous referees for their invaluable suggestions. J	Khan, S; Khokher, Z; Simin, T				Khan, Saqib; Khokher, Zeigham; Simin, Timothy			The Information Content of a Nonlinear Macro-Finance Model for Commodity Prices	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							STOCHASTIC CONVENIENCE YIELD; TERM STRUCTURE; DYNAMICS; EQUILIBRIUM; FUTURES; BEHAVIOR	State-of-the-art term structure models of commodity prices have serious difficulties extrapolating the prices of long-maturity futures contracts from short-dated contracts. This situation is problematic for valuing real commodity-linked assets. We estimate a nonlinear four-factor continuous time model of commodity price dynamics. The model nests many previous specifications. To estimate the model, we use crude oil prices and inventories. The inventory data and nonlinear price dynamics have a large impact on oil price forecasts. The additional factor in our model compared with current three-factor models has a significant impact on model-implied long-maturity futures prices.	[Khan, Saqib] Univ Regina, Regina, SK, Canada; [Khokher, Zeigham] Tulane Univ, New Orleans, LA 70118 USA; [Simin, Timothy] Penn State Univ, University Pk, PA 16802 USA	University of Regina; Tulane University; Pennsylvania Commonwealth System of Higher Education (PCSHE); Pennsylvania State University; Pennsylvania State University - University Park	Khokher, Z (corresponding author), Tulane Univ, AB Freeman Sch Business, 7 McAlister Dr, New Orleans, LA 70118 USA.	zkhokher@tulane.edu			Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada [410-2003-1540]	Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada(Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC))	The first draft of this paper was completed when the first two authors were at Western University in 2005. J	Bena, J; Xu, T				Bena, Jan; Xu, Ting			Competition and Ownership Structure of Closely Held Firms	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							PRODUCT MARKET COMPETITION; IMPORT COMPETITION; MANAGERIAL OWNERSHIP; CORPORATE GOVERNANCE; LARGE SHAREHOLDERS; CAPITAL STRUCTURE; IMPACT; POWER; RISK; DETERMINANTS	We study how product market competition affects firms' ownership structures using a large sample of closely held firms in eighteen European countries. We show that firms operating in more competitive environments have lower inside ownership and that the stakes of their outside shareholders are more dispersed. These results are explained by competition increasing the need to raise external equity and reducing private control benefits. Our findings suggest that, by changing corporate ownership structure, competition mitigates incentive misalignment among shareholders, leading to better firm performance and gains in economic efficiency.	[Bena, Jan; Xu, Ting] Univ British Columbia, Sauder Sch Business, Vancouver, BC, Canada	University of British Columbia	Bena, J (corresponding author), Univ British Columbia, Sauder Sch Business, Dept Finance, 2053 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z2, Canada.	jan.bena@sauder.ubc.ca	Bena, Jan/H-2942-2014	Bena, Jan/0000-0002-7235-8242	Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC) of Canada	Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC) of Canada(Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC))	We are grateful for helpful comments from Francesca Cornelli (the Editor), two anonymous referees, Murray Carlson, Vicente Cunat, Sudipto Dasgupta, David De Angelis, Espen Eckbo, Fabiana Gomez, Yaniv Grinstein, Stepan Jurajda, Adam Kolasinski, Kai Li, Randall Morck, Hernan Ortiz-Molina, Giorgo Sertsios, Elena Simintzi, Erin Smith, Sheri Tice, and Motohiro Yogo, as well as seminar participants at the Western Finance Association Meetings (Monterey); European Finance Association Meetings (Lugano); Bristol/Manchester Third Annual Corporate Finance Conference (Bristol); USC Finance, Organization, and Markets (FOM) Conference; Revelstoke Finance Group Meetings; Financial Management Association Asian Meetings (Tokyo); Financial Management Association Annual Meetings (Orlando); Tsinghua University; University of Alberta; University of British Columbia; and University of Rochester. J	Anderson, EW; Cheng, AR				Anderson, Evan W.; Cheng, Ai-Ru (Meg)			Robust Bayesian Portfolio Choices	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article						G11; C11; D81	STOCK RETURN PREDICTABILITY; NAIVE DIVERSIFICATION; MODEL; UNCERTAINTY; PARAMETER; SELECTION; MARKOWITZ	We propose a Bayesian-averaging portfolio choice strategy with excellent out-of-sample performance. Every period a new model is born that assumes means and covariances are constant over time. Each period we estimate model parameters, update model probabilities, and compute robust portfolio choices by taking into account model uncertainty, parameter uncertainty, and non-stationarity. The portfolio choices achieve higher out-of-sample Sharpe ratios and certainty equivalents than rolling window schemes, the 1/N approach, and other leading strategies do on a majority of 24 datasets.	[Anderson, Evan W.; Cheng, Ai-Ru (Meg)] No Illinois Univ, De Kalb, IL 60115 USA	Northern Illinois University	Anderson, EW (corresponding author), No Illinois Univ, Dept Econ, 515 Zulauf, De Kalb, IL 60115 USA.	ewanderson@niu.edu	Anderson, Evan/AAT-1512-2020	Cheng, Airu/0000-0002-1843-7863; J	Gale, D; Gottardi, P				Gale, Douglas; Gottardi, Piero			Capital Structure, Investment, and Fire Sales	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							TAX ARBITRAGE; EQUILIBRIUM; EXTERNALITIES; BANKRUPTCY; DEBT; FINANCE	We study a dynamic general equilibrium model in which firms choose their investment level and capital structure, trading off the tax advantages of debt against the risk of costly default. Bankruptcy costs are endogenous, as bankrupt firms are forced to liquidate their assets, resulting in a fire sale if the market is illiquid. When the corporate income tax rate is positive, firms have a unique optimal capital structure. In equilibrium, firms default with positive probability and their assets are liquidated at fire-sale prices. The equilibrium features underinvestment and is constrained inefficient. In particular there is too little debt and default.	[Gale, Douglas] NYU, New York, NY 10003 USA; [Gale, Douglas] Univ London Imperial Coll Sci Technol & Med, London SW7 2AZ, England; [Gottardi, Piero] European Univ Inst, Florence, Italy; [Gottardi, Piero] Univ Venice, I-30123 Venice, Italy	New York University; Imperial College London; European University Institute; Universita Ca Foscari Venezia	Gale, D (corresponding author), Univ London Imperial Coll Sci Technol & Med, Sch Business, Tanaka Bldg,South Kensington Campus, London SW7 2AZ, England.	douglas.gale@imperial.ac.uk			EUI Research Council, MIUR Prin [2010NE9L9Z-004]; Brevan Howard Centre at Imperial College	EUI Research Council, MIUR Prin; Brevan Howard Centre at Imperial College	We are grateful to the Editor, Itay Goldstein, and two anonymous referees for very useful comments. J	Back, K; Crotty, K				Back, Kerry; Crotty, Kevin			The Informational Role of Stock and Bond Volume	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							THE-COUNTER MARKETS; CORPORATE-BONDS; TRADING COSTS; INTRADAY ANALYSIS; SECURITY DESIGN; LIQUIDITY; EQUITY; TRANSPARENCY; EFFICIENCY; PRICE	In a Kyle (1985) model, the sign of the correlation between a firm's debt and equity returns is the same as the sign of the cross-market Kyle's lambda. The sign is positive (negative) if private information concerns the mean (risk) of the firm's assets. We show empirically that information conveyed by order flows is primarily about asset means. The cross-market lambdas are quite large; consequently, the portions of bond and stock returns explained by order flows are highly correlated, even though the order flows themselves are virtually uncorrelated. J	Biais, B; Rochet, JC; Woolley, P				Biais, Bruno; Rochet, Jean-Charles; Woolley, Paul			Dynamics of Innovation and Risk	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							MORAL HAZARD; INVESTMENT	We study the dynamics of an innovative industry in which agents learn about the likelihood of negative shocks. Managers can exert risk prevention effort to mitigate the consequences of shocks. If no shock occurs, confidence improves, attracting managers to the innovative sector. But, when confidence becomes high, inefficient managers exerting low risk-prevention effort also enter. This stimulates growth, while reducing risk prevention. The longer the boom, the larger the losses if a shock occurs. Although these dynamics arise in the first-best, asymmetric information generates excessive entry of inefficient managers, earning informational rents, inflating the innovative sector, and increasing its vulnerability. J	Gaul, L; Uysal, P				Gaul, Lewis; Uysal, Pinar			Can Equity Volatility Explain the Global Loan Pricing Puzzle?	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article						G10; G20; G30	IDIOSYNCRATIC VOLATILITY; RISK	This paper examines whether unobservable differences in firm volatility are responsible for the global loan pricing puzzle, which is the observation that corporate loan interest rates appear to be lower in Europe than in the United States. We analyze whether equity volatility, an error prone measure of firm volatility, can explain this difference in loan spreads. We show that using equity volatility in OLS regressions will result in biased and inconsistent estimates of the difference in U.S. and European loan spreads. We use instrumental variable methods to identify consistent estimates and find no difference in U.S. and European loan spreads.	[Uysal, Pinar] Ecole Polytech Fed Lausanne, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland	Swiss Federal Institutes of Technology Domain; Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne	Uysal, P (corresponding author), Ecole Polytech Fed Lausanne, Chair Int Finance, Stn 5,Odyssea ODY 2 17, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland.	pinar.uysal@ep.ch						Acharya V.V., 2011, NATL BUR EC RES; Amihud Y, 2002, J FINANC MARK, V5, P31, DOI 10.1016/S1386-4181(01)00024-6; [Anonymous], 2011, ECONOMETRIC ANAL; Bartram SM, 2012, J FINANC, V67, P1329, DOI 10.1111/j.1540-6261.2012.01749.x; Bartram SM, 2011, J FINANC QUANT ANAL, V46, P967, DOI 10.1017/S0022109011000275; Becker B., 2011, WORKING PAPER; Bekaert G., 2011, INT FINANCIAL MANAGE; BLACKBURN M, 1992, Q J ECON, V107, P1421, DOI 10.2307/2118394; BRADLEY M, 1984, J FINANC, V39, P857, DOI 10.2307/2327950; Brandt MW, 2010, REV FINANC STUD, V23, P863, DOI 10.1093/rfs/hhp087; Campbell JY, 2008, J FINANC, V63, P2899, DOI 10.1111/j.1540-6261.2008.01416.x; Carey M., 2007, J FINANC, V33, P389; Choi JD, 2012, TECHNICAL REPORT; Djankov S, 2008, J FINANC ECON, V88, P430, DOI 10.1016/j.jfineco.2007.02.007; Djankov S, 2007, J FINANC ECON, V84, P299, DOI 10.1016/j.jfineco.2006.03.004; Han YF, 2011, REV FINANC STUD, V24, P1590, DOI 10.1093/rfs/hhq140; Houston J., 2007, WORKING PAPER; La Porta R, 2006, J FINANC, V61, P1, DOI 10.1111/j.1540-6261.2006.00828.x; MERTON RC, 1974, J FINANC, V29, P449, DOI 10.2307/2978814; ROSENBAUM PR, 1983, BIOMETRIKA, V70, P41, DOI 10.1093/biomet/70.1.41; Santos JAC, 2011, REV FINANC STUD, V24, P1916, DOI 10.1093/rfs/hhq115; Strahan P. J	Garmaise, MJ				Garmaise, Mark J.			The Attractions and Perils of Flexible Mortgage Lending	REVIEW OF FINANCIAL STUDIES			English	Article							CORPORATE-FINANCE; CONSUMER-BEHAVIOR; CREDIT; SELECTION; RISK	A mortgage program that offered borrowers greater flexibility in the timing of repayments increased a bank's volume by over 35%. Loans in the program exhibited superior performance. Despite this, a regression discontinuity analysis shows that the causal impact of offering flexibility was to attract borrowers to the bank who experienced quadruple the average delinquency rate. These contrasting findings are driven by the fact that the bank engaged in ex post sorting of stronger borrowers into the flexible program. This sorting masked the ex ante adverse selection effects that offering flexibility had on the entire borrowing pool.
